This is way more common than people recognize. I struggled to varying degrees for about 4 years. It does get better, but it requires support and potentially medication (in my case, I needed high dose antihistamines to calm my immune system after giving birth, but it took a while to get this diagnosis). Please be gentle with yourself during this time. If you can take more time off, go part-time, or work from home, I highly recommend it. In retrospect, I wish I had listened to my body more. Also - your career will be here when you are ready, so don‚Äôt feel like you have to keep the same pace that you did before; it‚Äôs just temporary.

Doctors you can ask for help: OBGYN, PCP, therapist, any specialist that you have an upcoming appointment with, your child‚Äôs pediatrician - they can all either help or point you in the right direction.

It is more common than you think and it is not your fault ‚ô•Ô∏è I‚Äôm still struggling with it after nearly 2 years

Everyone has a unique situation and experience and it requires self awareness (which you have) confidence building activities and boundaries (which many people struggle with)

Additionally support from your line manager and mentor to set you up for success x

Hi, I had a very hard time when I came back after Mat leave. Big 4 is very freaking demanding and doesn't leave much time for anything else. In my case I went to a 80% reduced schedule and that allowed me to nit work the "extra" aka nights and weekends. This gave me time with my son and allowed me to reduce my workload so I wasn't rushing/ exhausted and not doing my best. Yes the pay cut sucks but if u can make it work I highly recommend it. I wouldn't still be at a big 4 without this option.

You are not alone feeling this way. I still do after 3 yrs from having my last. I manage it a little better now than initially. I used to feel so efficient at work and after having kiddos I immediately felt as if I lost part of my memory. I became really hard on myself, and lost a lot of confidence. Therapy has been extremely helpful and support from friends and loved ones. Continue to talk about it as you are doing now and get support. Most importantly don‚Äôt be hard on yourself. You are stronger than you think ;)
You will feel you are not doing enough at work or home. But you are. Give yourself some grace.

I almost got hospitalized before realizing that I have a mild postpartum OCD with major depression and anxiety. Currently on medical leave and doing group therapy, individual therapy and taking medications.

I regret not talking to a psychologist earlier. I suffered silently for too long. I vented online a lot but kept white knuckling through all of it.

Don‚Äôt Google it. Just talk to a perinatal mental health specialist, not just a random psychiatrist/therapist.

I can‚Äôt thank everyone enough for the comments. I have truly, fundamentally not been okay. There are not too many newer moms in our team, and it just felt like I‚Äôm the broken one. I‚Äôm sorry that people have experienced this but I don‚Äôt feel as alone.
I reached out to my doctor about a new post partum drug and am trying all the other things. But it looks like time and work are needed to overcome.

EY offers career coaching to new parents transitioning back. I have loved the program and done it with all of my children. Check the materials from the leave team for the link to sign up. Lyra is also available.

I took an extended leave after my second and woke up in a panic one morning about 4-6 weeks out from starting back and my son starting daycare. That turned in to terrible depression and anxiety and sent me spiraling and I found out you can have PPD/PPA start that late after giving birth. I had no idea. It was bad but once I found a med that worked for me, it helped me get my wits back and think a bit more rationally and clearly.

I understand what it‚Äôs like to be the only mom on the team. So many don‚Äôt understand or empathize. It‚Äôs a tough road. From that point, I requested to only have a female who is a mom as a counselor. I had to go on a FWA to maintain any sort of decent schedule. It did get better, but it took a lot of people getting involved to help find something that would work for me/my family.

A therapist really helped me. It took me quite a bit of time to get used to my new life as a mother. Going from living for yourself to living for this tiny baby is such a mindset shift. Let alone trying to juggle work! Im praying for you üôèüèº
Yes. I also live with OCD. I really believe the stigma will continue to exist until it‚Äôs normalized.

I live with it too but OCD also has its benefits, especially for employers. For starters, CDs, PMs and producers love me b/c I deliver buttoned-up work on time and constantly communicate with all stakeholders throughout the assignment process.

If you do decide to have the conversation, don‚Äôt go in sheepishly and apologizing for what you think are failures on your part. Go in confidently like a journalist reporting on all the facets that make you, you, and how they benefit the team. Also, humor goes a long way.

I pretty much assume all creatives have OCD.

I am in Canada, so I don't know where you are or what the laws are like, but I have AuDHD and I disclose. At the very least I recommend disclosing to HR and your direct manager.

1. I have two conditions tied to a perception of performance so I do it to protect myself
2. It gives your manager a chance to know and manage you better
3. I promise you that your masking abilities have probably softened since the Pandemic so if you're going into the office occasionally it's something someone somewhere has noticed

I have OCD as well. Although it‚Äôs not the kind people think they know (nervously organizing things). It‚Äôs the kind where I obsess about my health constantly. It reached a real breaking point during the pandemic, as you might imagine.

So I ended up confiding in my bosses. I think it helped explain things and made them more empathetic. At the same time, it felt like I had had ‚Äúothered‚Äù myself in a negative way.

Just sending you a big hug, OP! I get defensive about people using real diagnoses as casual phrases a lot. I had to ask my team lead to tell people to stop saying our project "gave them PTSD," for instance, because myself and another team member actually have PTSD. I've had a Managing Director call a client "bipolar"... my grandmother actually was bipolar and her daughter, my aunt, is. It's not a laughing matter. I'm AuDHD and have had to tell people at work that using the r-word is absolutely unacceptable and that no, "everyone is a little ADHD/ADD" is not true. I've even heard Schizophrenic used this way in a work setting. It's abhorrent how people treat real disabilities so cavalierly.

I'm so sorry that people are inconsiderate jerks. No one deserves for their suffering to be belittled or minimized or made into a punchline. It's hard enough having invisible disabilities without people insulting what those of us who live with them endure by treating them as a casual joke. ‚ù§Ô∏è

What kind of accommodations are you looking for? Whether or not it‚Äôs difficult will largely depend on your employer unfortunately. In theory, it should be easy to go to your employer (HR if you have them or manager if not) with a doctors note specifying your restrictions and how that restriction will help you perform your job. Sadly discrimination does still exist, but I do think it‚Äôs getting better. And if you are performing well, that‚Äôs all a lot of partners care about at the end of the day. The other good thing is, you do not need to disclose your specific disability to your manager. It may help in some situations, but in others (especially mental health) you may want to just ask for the accommodation.

I have a recent accommodation for another health condition (but one that is often stigmatized, not as much as mental health though). My manager does know what my condition is. I work from home as needed and have some minor changes to my office set up. Very easy to secure.

The game is rigged. I have Apergers, but I am extremely high functioning. I got DOUBLE TIME on all my exams in college and in law school, SAT and LSAT, MPRE, AND THE BAR EXAM.

I have a stack of paperwork of over 300 pages going back to when I was 4 years old from doctors. It‚Äôs not hard at all. It‚Äôs a fucking pain in the god damn ass to gather up all the paperwork and organize it in a pretty little bow though. Took me about six months.

Not sure what you mean by ‚Äúwithout any reliance on medical help,‚Äù but this is definitely something I would talk to a therapist or psychiatrist who specializes in OCD about. They can help individualize what types of coping mechanisms would work best for your situation. No one here is going to be able to do that for you unfortunately.

Something that has helped me is the concept of ridiculing those thought patterns/compulsions first heard about it in Man‚Äôs Search for Meaning by Viktor Frankl. Essentially you take the power out of those thoughts by making fun of them and acknowledging they are not rational. The mind is powerful and my anxiety used to manifest as a feeling of pressure on my back, this method allowed me to challenge my irrational thought patterns/compulsions.
I know you are trying to stay away from medical help, but ERP therapy works well and you can get it through NOCD virtually.

I have been in therapy since I was 16 (30 now). I have both diagnosed OCD, ADHD/ASD, and Depression. I have been on Prozac for 14 years with stings of non-medicated months.

OCD is considerably easier to keep in check with higher dosages of SSRIs. View medication as a means to lower the ‚Äúbaseline‚Äù level of symptoms. There will still need to be skills learned to compensate for the rest - that is where CBT and DBT come in to play. If you wish to not take medicine then I would explore those options first. Just know, I am not aware of anyone truly OCD that has had luck with just those.

May I ask why you are opposed to medicine? My quality of life improved (albeit with side effects) when I became medicated.

Thank you so much for sharing your experience. I‚Äôve tried an SSRI and a tricyclic and had intolerable adverse responses to both. I‚Äôm also concerned about the long term side effects even if another SSRI is more tolerable.

ERP (plus CBT and some DBT skills) have been working so far, albeit slowly, to improve both OCD and depression. My OCD specialist reports that not all patients benefit from medication. So I am curious if others also found a non-medication route to health and what that looks like. (I‚Äôm of course working with a psychiatrist.)

I see! Honestly the side effects are pretty bad. I haven‚Äôt heard of ERP. I‚Äôll do some research or bring it up to my therapist. Anecdotally, I have heard that OCD treatment is a tough nut to crack and really progress can be quite slow. I would say any progress is good progress. Took me quite a few years to get in a decent spot (~8 years). That‚Äôs a long time but in the grand scheme of your life should hopefully set you up for the future.

Thank you so much, Deloitte 1. I‚Äôm so glad you‚Äôve made good progress and are in a decent spot.

Exposure response prevention (ERP) is explained more here: https://www.treatmyocd.com/what-is-ocd/what-is-erp

As a note, I‚Äôve found that it‚Äôs ideal to work with therapist who is a specialist in ERP and does it 75% or more of their time. There is no official training or certificate for OCD and ERP providers, and so therapists will really differ in their knowledge.

OCD is a challenging condition but I agree that treating it will set up a much better future.

Currently at EYP, I have a mixed view. For the most part, I kind of agree. However, there are ex-MBB/T2 partners which bring in quality work where you‚Äôd get good exposure. I‚Äôve first-hand seen us win a few proposals competing against K/OW/MBB, though we usually compete on a cost basis rather than quality.

The other draw is if you‚Äôre originally e.g. American (where EYP is a strong brand) and you weren‚Äôt competitive enough in the US to land a solid strategy consulting gig, doing EYP in MENA for a year or two is honestly not a bad idea. It‚Äôs not like US recruiters could tell re the relatively unestablished presence of EYP in the region lol.

Aside from all that, I‚Äôve seen people start at EYP and end up at OW/K/MBB. Doesn‚Äôt happen all the time but it seems to happen.
